My friend's mom who was also my mom's friend back in the 90's used to sell Mary Kay cosmetics. My mom would buy some of the products to help her out from time to time, but she would never actually use them. She said she didn't like the well it felt on her skin, but she thought if she didn't buy some she might lose a friend she held dear, and their family was struggling with money. It took a couple of years before she finally stopped selling Mary Kay and it took her husband threatening divorce to get her to stop, as they had boxes of unsold product just lying around their house. I never got told how much money they went into debt for, but both of my friends parents were working 2 jobs each for quite some time to recover from this. As they weren't home a lot, I remember my friend coming over to my house for dinner at least 2-3 times a week or my mom bringing the left overs or extra food she made over to their house from time to time as well.

I had a uniquely odd recruiting story. When I was in college, I answered a Craigslist job listing where a group of us gathered at a rented out office space to "interview" for CutCo, a knife MLM. They then had us sit in chairs while this lady joylessly cut random things: Tomatoes, rope, ground it against a rock to then cut another tomato. Absolute silence and a neutral face the entire time. They then went on a dry spiel about the potential earnings and, after, pulled me aside to say I "stood out" to them as somebody with potential... something they seemed to have told everyone. I almost fell for it too until my mom did some more research on it and saved me from making a fool of myself.

MLMs can be used for illegal money laundering, integrating illicit funds into the legal banking system.  Multilevel marketing schemes, often referred to as MLMs, unfortunately present a vulnerability that can be exploited for criminal activities, specifically the nefarious practice of money laundering.  Individuals or groups engaged in generating illicit funds from unlawful sources can leverage the structure of MLM companies to disguise the origin of these dirty money flows.   By passing these ill-gotten gains through the operations of an MLM, which often involves numerous transactions and a perceived legitimate business model, the funds are effectively laundered, making their source difficult to trace.  This process allows the previously illegal money to seamlessly enter and become integrated within the formal and legitimate banking infrastructure, effectively sanitizing the funds and making them available for use without raising red flags about their true, criminal origins.   Only insiders understand how they function.  It is exclusively individuals with privileged access and intimate knowledge of these systems who truly grasp the intricate mechanisms and operational processes by which they function.  Only those designated as insiders possess the comprehensive understanding necessary to fully comprehend the internal workings and operational dynamics, allowing them to perceive precisely how these entities carry out their designated tasks and achieve their objectives.

Enagic/Kangen Water is widely considered a pyramid scheme.  Only top leaders (6A2-3 and above), less than 1%, profit, while over 99% lose money.  This is the destructive nature of MLMs; they cost participants money, friends, and family.  Research it on Google.  Enagic's Kangen Water business, with its MLM structure and misleading health claims, is frequently criticized as a scam.  Deceptive marketing, often likened to "snake oil," avoids direct mentions of "Enagic" or "Kangen Water," instead using mentorship claims to recruit.  Be wary of exaggerated health benefits and high-pressure sales tactics linked to these products.  There is no strong scientific evidence and medical journals that support claims of the benefits of Alkaline Water as a disease therapy or having significant health benefits, fresh coconut water is best and deserves a mention.

I came across this post and felt the need to clarifyâ€”labeling "Bhip" as a scam without concrete evidence is misleading. Unfounded accusations can harm reputations and create unnecessary fear. If there are genuine concerns, itâ€™s far more constructive to share clear proof or specific examples instead of making broad statements. From my perspective, Bhip operates under strict regulations and industry standards. They've been active for decadesâ€”if they truly were a pyramid scheme, they wouldn't still exist (worth thinking about). Letâ€™s keep discussions factual so people can form informed opinions. Often, such claims stem from one person's negative experience or past unrelated scams. Just a reminder: good and bad companies exist everywhere. Always DYOR before jumping to conclusions or spreading unverified claims.

Everyone, the way to ward off any MLM distributor is simple. Once they are ready to recruit you, and have you fill out their application, say to the recruiter "I need a $2000 signing bonus to get started!" Thank you mom for teaching me how to do business. Because I was almost recruited by these MLM/Pyramid Scheme business. The first you have to look out for is the way they talk. If the way they talk to you like you're joining in a cult then it's a red flag. Second outrageous claims on their products. Third are earnings that are too sweet to hear like 50000 dollars a month. Fourth are trips that are "said" to be funded by the company. Fifth is the classic pyramid recruitment. Sixth are the requirements like buying packages to become a member and recruit or spread this to others. Seventh saying Artists likes this product and they endorse them. Those seven are among the many I have notice in these schemes.

My dad wanted me to work for Amway like he does, and set up a meeting for me with one of their representatives in order to sell the position. Now, I had no idea what Amway was at the time. The representative said things to me like "You want to have a game console? Well if you work for Amway you can get all the consoles!" and similar stuff like that. I was fairly engrossed by the pitch, but then I spotted something on one of the presentation slides he was using: A small line of text saying "This is not a pyramid scheme". This one sentence immediately rang all the alarm bells in my head, and as soon as the meeting was done I went back to my room and searched up everything I could about the company, found out how terrible it is, and promptly proceeded to decline any following requests from my dad to talk with Amway any further.  Thanks, Dad. You may be a Daily Wire watching guy working for a pyramid scheme who thinks that "men are invading women's sports", but you got me to learn about MLMs and how awful they are. That's the one thing I'll give you.

No they are not. A business hierarchy is not the same as a pyramid scheme. If you can't see the difference, you are either not aware of what a pyramid scheme actually is or you're trying to promote a pyramid scheme (or something very close to a pyramid scheme).
Tupperware is one of the few good ones. They are actually useful
They represent the minority of MLMs who actually sell a good product and whose business model actually works by selling to consumers instead of profiting off of recruitment.

Tupperware reps still make most of their money selling products to end consumers, not by recruiting other salespeople. Also with Tupperware you do not have to keep ordering product month after month to keep your status. If people come to the parties or want to order online, they are ordering directly from Tupperware. The rep isn't holding thousands of dollars worth of product in their home. It is multi-level in that you can recruit others and get a commission off their sales. But they don't put pressure on people to keep recruiting, their main focus is still on selling the product to end customers

I have a neighbor who is one of those very few people who made a lot of money selling Mary Kay products.  But the truth is that she did not actually sell because her money comes from the many distributors who are under her.  She even bought a house in El Salvador and makes money br renting it.  Mary Kay even gave her a private car.  But she does not know the hell and tears that the other salespeople go through to stay employed and pay her salary.  One day one of her top distributors was diagnosed with a serious disease.  This lady who has never believed in divine healing and criticized me and my family for having bible study meetings suddenly came crying to us, begging us to pray for that lady's healing, since that lady contributed a large percent of my neighbor's salary.  She did not care when the poor salespeople got sick because they were not top performers who made money for her.  But this neighbor of mine made a huge mistake.  She kept all her merchandise at home and had frequent parties to show off her expensive products and luxury home.  This creates an opportunity to tempt people to rob you.  One day her home was broken into.  Some of these companies do have good quality products but it is the way they scam people that is wrong.  This woman had thousands of dollars worth of products as w ell as a lot of expensive jewelry at her home.  The thieves took over $80,000 worth of products and jewelry that day.  What's worse, she saw it all!!!  Yes, she was entering her home and saw the house in a big mess and heard voices from the other rooms.  She decided to hide in a closet and not say a word.  She saw that they had guns so there was nothing she could do but hide and watch through a crack in the door how the thieves took all of her things.  She did not want to be shot.  The police came the next day but they could not find the burglars.  They gave her a free alarm system and offered to pay the monthly fee. This lady had to get therapy for her trauma and has since retired.  But I would be even more traumatized if I knew that I was abusing other people. If I was rich but I knew that the people who contributed to my wealth went through some serious abuses, I could not live with myself.  I would always be asking, I wonder if a child did not get any new clothes to pay for my luxury lifestyle?  Is it fair that my sellers are doing more work than me but earning a lot less?

two times, I got sucked into the surrounding sub-cultures of these MLMs. First was Arbonne, whose water additive powders did initially give me the energy I needed (but then I realized I was lacking energy due to depression and this was a temp placebo effect/just the first water entering my system bc chronically dehydrated) and second, a religious-based subdivision of Amway I believe that preyed on the fact that I wanted a healthier relationship with my abusive ex. They literally based their whole pitch and every event afterwards on healing relationships and were leveraging Christianity as a way to hook people. I started recognizing the signs and we hadn't invested any money, leaving successfully. But the "friends" who roped us in never talked to us again. It's sad when you think about it, bc the low-level salespeople are just as oblivious to the negative effects. They have no friends and are encouraged to dissociate from anyone who is unwilling to join or leaves, so that they can "focus on building [their] small business." It's def cult-like.

I remember growing up and having my family get involved with these schemes. Thankfully they never got to far into them, but I still have people close that keep doing this. Its both heart breaking and infuriating to me that these kinds of scammers can get away with this crap.

Almost caught up in one earlier this year, one of my old classmates from high school kept talking about it and the amazing benefits and all, I kept ignoring it since I already had a job, but I started my search for a new one and he has texted me again about it. The whole thing was kinda off everything was very vague, he kept trying to set a meet-up with me to "show me around" just so I could see what it was like, and I agreed. I walked in and got a whole blown interview, which mainly involved recruiting new people to get money (it was for an insurance company) I asked about where you find new clients and I never really got a straightforward answer, meaning their focus was on hiring new people.Â   They sure painted a good picture, but I still kept wondering where they got their money from, if we get paid based on recruitment. They kept mentioning their recognitions and how they were on the Forbes list, etc. They offered this "cheaper course" for licensing which happened to be $125, I felt like an idiot for agreeing (I'm a people pleaser).They had finally given me the name of the company (which hadn't been mentioned until then) I went home to search up the name and all these red flags came up. I tried canceling my credit card asap but it had went through.   And then I got charged a $25 MONTLY FEE!!? LIKE WHAT (this was a month later; I had cut contact with them at this point) I emailed that I had never agreed to it and that I wanted to cancel my subscription, (they said that I had agreed to it by signing the agreement contract, always read the fine lines) and only through that claim was I able to find out I could get my refund for the $150 as well (which I had to keep persisting for (they only refunded portions at a time,maybe hoping I wouldn't realize)). At the end I only lost $25, which is still bad but compared to the $200 I would of lost... yea  But nonetheless, I learned my lesson. This was really crazy to me especially seeing my old friend who tried to recruit me, I entered his insta profile and it literally seems like that company is his whole personality now. Definitely wouldn't call him a friend.  ALWAYS BE AWARE!!!       btw this was Primerica.

If the products are good, then let customers order them online directly from Herbalife. There shouldn't be levels and levels of distributors at this point. It's not necessary and definitely not necessary to keep recruiting a downline when most people are now doing their own research and shopping online. I actually know of a vitamin company who got rid of their entire MLM structure and now sells products through their own corporate website directly to customers. They are also now selling their products into health food stores, drug stores, etc. They realized they could make more money by national advertising and putting their resources into social media marketing, Google Ad words and sponsoring social media affiliates. it's cut down on their paperwork, their reporting, etc by getting rid of the thousands of independent distributors they had

Leaving this here for anyone who came across this video. John Oliver is brilliant. I had this video in my mind when I was being lectured by an MLM agent. Helped me better understand what was happening. This is my experience.   I'm from south India. I moved to punjab (a state in north India) for studies. I always knew what a pyramid scheme was. But I didn't know how these people get you. There are several organizations that operate in India, in my home state and EVEN within my university that I was studying in. They operate is most big and popular universities. The people that I mostly ran into work for "E-biz". But there are several other companies. Their front is that they offer software engineering courses to learn programming languages and business management software. But they're an MLM and you understand how they operate at this point. The real problem is how they get people to join them. They start off by bullshit motivational monologues about being your own boss, having people who work for you, how much you could gain by joining them in terms of personal skills, business skills and this is how rich tech CEOs like bill gates and others started and function. If you're not convinced immediately, they'll try to get you buy flexing things they or others in the company bought and tell you that you can earn a lot of money and if you're still not convinced, they'll you the sentiment card, asking you if you'd like to pay back your parents for all the money they spent on you for your higher education.  I ran into 3 different people (three times into the first guy, who didn't remember me even for the 3rd time). All of them spout the exact same bullshit about being your boss, learn management and personal skills, earning money, making parents happy. They'll also ask you to call your parents to talk to them instead. Don't. If you understand what's going on, walk away. You won't make any money from this, their courses are garbage and outdated and can found on the internet for free. But what's sad is that... All the people who try to recruit you... Are also students who fell for the scam.   Don't fall for any of this. If you wanna hear them out, sure... But don't waste anything but time on these people. And even that, only if you don't instantly understand what is going on. I didn't either when I ran to these people for the first 2 times but still, I'm lucky that I only lost a few hours to these people and not money. Be safe.

My wife got drawn into the Mk makeup "business." I warned her against it but she's a grown woman who can make her own decisions.  The women she was working with were...odd.  They shared a cult-like appreciation for the company.     So of course she bought a ton of product to keep available.   It didn't sell.   After sitting on the shelf for months, I asked her what she planned to do with it.  She snapped at me saying "I'm going to sell it!"  This was starting to cause friction in our marriage.  I felt second-place to their cult.     I lost my temper when she said she wanted to fly to a national conference on our dime.  Hell no!  Thank god she didn't go.   She asked me to come to a dinner at her, I guess "boss's" house.   I couldn't believe what I heard there.  Some of the women they invited were single moms or women with limited income.  They flat out told them to fly to the national conference.  Can't afford to? Put it on the credit card and pay it off later!  Yikes.   I told my wife we were leaving.  We argued all the way home.   The turning point was when she had makeup parties at our house scheduled, and nobody showed up.  She had enough.   I said don't be surprised if those ladies don't talk to her anymore if she quits. Guess what,  that's exactly what happened.   They shunned her and the product that's sitting in our house, expired.  They were so phoney.   They're your friends only when you're buying product from them.   There's a happy ending.   She realized I was right, we cut our losses,  and now she helps people stay out of these pyramid schemes.  We are still happily married.   Sometimes we just make mistakes.

In college I was approached by two kids trying to get me to sign up for some sort of energy drink pyramid scheme. - I invited them over to have a beer and explain the error of their ways. I told them I had no interest in joining onto a pyramid scheme and they vehemently denied it was one. I pulled out a piece of paper and asked them how the organizational hierarchy was laid out, then began drawing it exactly as they described it. - A few layers deep, I drew a border around it and asked what shape it looked like. "Uhhhh - a triangle?"  One of my friends was watching tv in the next room and chimed in, "IT'S A PYRAMID YOU FUCKS."  They legitimately didn't realize what they'd gotten themselves into until that point.

46 years ago, I married into a family that was heavy into Amway. We had been married just a few months when we were invited for a weekend visit.  It was full-force Amway all weekend. The more I heard, the more livid I became.  I became a pariah in the family when I refused to get involved or let my husband invest in their latest scheme. I not only refused to get involved, but I also threatened to destroy the tapes they sent home with my husband to recruit me.  Over the years I watched them flip back and forth into Amway, each time to make a better shot at getting rich. Then it was TravelMax [That one was promoted as climbing a ladder, not a pyramid,].  And Nikken. And vitamins. Every get rich scheme was attractive to them.  Their eyes glowed as they gave their spiel.  Always trying to make money fast without effort.  Pictures of mansions and million-dollar RVs on the fridge. They never learned their lesson.  They never got rich.   I never heard them say they had been snookered. Last I knew, they were still reaching for that elusive pot of gold.

Warning to everyone out there I was roped into something like this being a fresh college grad. I studied business in school with an interest in marketing. After school I looked for a lot of marketing jobs and ran into a â€œopportunityâ€ that sounded nice. It was a smaller marketing firm that had little requirements to apply. I was supposed to be going in for a marketing executive job. The interview process was really short. It took as little as a week to get on board. Basically if you showed interest and had a pulse you were in. They prayed on young individuals like myself and there were a lot of people in my company that didnâ€™t even go to college. They promised this â€œgreat opportunityâ€ to â€œclimb the ladderâ€ and said within a few years you could reach a position to make six figures. When I went into my first day into the office they were really transparent about what I was actually going to be doing. Then I realized it wasnâ€™t the job I was looking for at all. They wanted my to do face-to-face marketing, direct sales, door-to-door, cold-callingâ€¦ whatever you want to call it. The company I worked for operated under a number of different names. Which was another big red flag. I would work 70-80+ hours standing outside for about 11hrs a day soliciting donations for charities such as Amnesty International, Doctors Without Borders, Covenant House, WWF, Greenpeace, etc. everything was scripted. When I first started I thought I was actually doing it for a good cause because I did believe in NPOs. The company culture changed when I didnâ€™t hit my â€œnumbersâ€ I was looked down upon, even humiliated. Iâ€™m not a type of person that would ever see myself in sales. Iâ€™m not a hard seller and often times when someone told me they didnâ€™t have the money or only wanted to donate one time Iâ€™d direct them to the charities website, which was actually frowned upon. Why would they scold you for not upselling for a charity and why would a charity not want to take in any money offered? That was another thing that was fishy. The main company I worked with out for Dallas was Lumos Marketing Group, but I actually worked under another company in the same office as Lumos called Rose Gold Talents. The same office also had a number of different names like Jamrock, Amethyst, and Synergy Solutions. Lumos Marketing Groups parent company was Credico. Which has a number of class action lawsuits against them for poor working conditions and labor law violations. The office was very generic with little furniture. We were put into this room every morning called â€œatmosphereâ€ where weâ€™d recite what they considered â€œfundamental principlesâ€ itâ€™s was very cult like and they would tell you to not everything down even if you learned it 100times before. I lost connection to my friends, family, even myselfâ€¦ they people I knew where the people in my office. Often times there were also relations with people in the office too because they were the only connections and relationships we hadâ€¦ this caused a lot of drama. You were told to reach certain quotas and would also go on â€œbusiness tripsâ€ around the US to different offices which were also all very generic from Nashville to New Yorkâ€¦ these offices also operated under many different names. You were promised a great opportunity but had to recruit people under you and train those under you. I often times had leaders above me that were younger and didnâ€™t even really know what the hell was going on either. Then youâ€™d reach a point where you could â€œopen your own officeâ€ and the more people you hired underneath you the more cut youâ€™d get out of the profitsâ€¦. Which really made me think how much of the money was actually going to the cause. I highly advise anyone looking for a job to be very wary of these companiesâ€¦.

A college professor, whom I respected deeply, tried to lure me into one of these.  After he was laid off by the university (after teaching for 35 years, with a 40-year-long career in all of the best companies), I assume that he got dragged into these due to his severance pay. I was one of these students who gave him the benefit of the doubt even after countless red flags during his pitch. At the meeting, he brings a second person (his "partner") who starts spewing all of the clichÃ©s, talking a lot but without saying anything.  I just said I wasn't interested and left. Then I warned my college colleagues about what had happened. Two friends later told me this professor tried to recruit them a couple of weeks later.  I feel sorry for this professor, to be honest. It's related to how the money flows within that pyramid shape.  'Leaders' in MLMs get percentages of their recruitments' sales, and that makes the bulk of their pay.  There is no guaranteed income for anyone, and often those at the bottom lose money.  Contrast this to corporations who are legally required to pay everyone at least minimum wage.

â€‹Â @ValFatherTimeÂ  Building up a team to earn "passive income", AKA, getting paid off the sales of others. How nice. And...what about the recruitment aspect, though? Because if I'm "building a team"...and you've built a team...and this conference I'm supposed to attend has thousands of other sellers who have "built a team"...who the hell am I selling to?! If I'm am independent contractor who's main job it is to sell a product or service and that's supposed to be the real way I make money (because if this isn't a pyramid scheme, making money off of recruiting shouldn't even be a thing), I've recruited my competition! And so has everyone in that conference. And so many other conferences across the country or across the world.   All of them and their "teams" are now in competition with me. If I'm trying to be the #1 seller, I need ALL you bastards to get the hell out of my way and stop selling. I want all of this revenue for myself! I've just made my job harder with a "team" and so has everyone else! This would be fine if there was a limit to the amount of sellers that could be in the company (you know, like a traditional, legitimate sales job has so that everyone isn't stepping on each other's toes), but there isn't!  And THAT is the part that I would love for you to try to make sense. Please, we are all waiting to hear how it makes good business sense that when you're supposed to be selling a product or service, the compensation plan tells you to instead bring in more people to also sell, diminishing the people available to sell to. I never considered joining an MLM in my life, and I think it's because I've always been very simple minded about how I look at them. I don't think people who get sucked into them aren't stupid or gullible, I just think they are overthinking things.  Basically I've been acquainted with tons of people, and even close to a couple people, selling all sorts of different mlm products. I didn't think about it deeply or know much about mlms. I just noticed that not one seller stayed with the mlm company for any length of time, usually less than a year. But I've never in 42 years known a person to still be with the same mlm company for a long time, say like even 3 years.     Also, of all those mlm sellers I knew,, not one single one actually made a real profit. The BEST outcome I'd heard was "oh I got out of selling that because it was hours and hours of work and I made almost nothing. You'd make way more with far less work just picking up a part time minimum wage job".  Mostly I'd hear stories about of the how mlm seller actually lost a bunch of money and never sold enough to cover costs.   I'm simple minded about it. I don't believe for a second that all those people I've encountered trying to be an mlm seller just didn't try hard enough or whatever and failed. If a business model is so shit more than 90 % of people who become sellers fail to make money then I'd never consider joining one. I don't care how fast you talk. Don't over think it. If it doesn't work for the vast majority don't do it.

Tell her to prove it to you. People love when they can lord it over on someone who resisted them. To do this you have to be willing to meet with her and have her show you everything, and you're going to approach it as an observer without always arguing about it. But set up some ground rules.   #1, she has to show you her actual accounting for her "business". You get to see receipts. You both go over how much money went out and how much came in. This way she can't hide the fact that she's losing money.  #2, she needs to go to a doctor with the Herbalife stuff in its packaging, and the doctor needs to explain to her whether these are good things and whether she should replace meals with them. But here's the catch: she makes the appointment with you in the room, and then later you call the hospital. Explain that you don't need them to give you private medical info, you just need to speak with Dr. So-And-So. When you have that person, explain that your mom made an appointment, she's bringing in this herbal supplement stuff, and you're coming in with her for the visit, and you're worried that it's all unhealthy unproven stuff and not real medicine. Most doctors are gonna be primed to tear the living daylights out of the supplements after that conversation. Again, present the situation, but let the doctor think it's all about his professional medical opinion. The best of all would be bringing in the health claims made by Herbalife like if they say it cures specific ailments, because the doc will be able to shut that down instantly.  #3, inoculate the rest of the family against her. Sit down with them in person, in private, each one alone. Explain the situation, say that they need to never give her money for this stuff, or participate in the company, and she's being scammed so she'll probably lie and ask for money for other things but it's really because of her Herbalife. And most importantly, they can never tell her that you said this.  #4, as much as you can, try to prevent her from going to cult meetings. When she says there's a big conference coming up, tell her you had already planned a getaway for just the two of you (and then go do that).   There's a chance she finds out you were working against her and then you find out which is stronger: the cult's grip on her or her love for you as a mother. It's possible for a person to be a lost cause because they became too brainwashed. Remember not to let her ruin your life.

This video popped up in my recommendations today, and I felt compelled to comment. I watched this the day it came out five years ago as a naive 23 year old, having heard of some of the companies but with no understanding of what an MLM was or how they operated.   About a month later, I was approached at my job by a girl about my age asking if I was interested in "helping people". I thought it was some kind of volunteering gig at a food bank or homeless shelter; it was Amway. I'm usually a big pushover, even with people I don't know very well, but because I'd watched this video, I knew enough to be suspicious of this girl and to ask the right questions about the company, the products, and how they operate. I got away from that interaction without an ounce of the guilt I usually feel for being firm or for denying my people-pleasing nature. Thank you John Oliver and the Last Week Tonight team for helping to protect a young 20-something from making a horrible mistake. â¤

That sucks, but they should have stoped when they realized they had like a month or two with red numbers. Sadly, they can't see their financial reality because they're: a) Desperate or b) ignorant or c) greedy Compensation plans are always on company websites, you should study them before joining. If the company asks you to buy a lot of products and recruit a certain number of people each month so that they can pay you, it's totally a pyramid scheme because most of the money comes from new distributors, instead of customers. If the product or service is way too expensive, there's nothing special about it, doesnÂ´t have scientific backup, there's another big red flag.  It's sad that there are still companies like these operating. I dare to say that mosts "MLM's" are pyramid schemes in disguise, and even if you join a consumer based MLM, you have not much chances of making lots of money out of it. It's a lie that everyone can have success in that industry, because not everyone likes to sell, and not everyone has great communication and leadership skills. A business that is primarily focused on getting distributors, is bound to fail.

He basically was saying yes it is a  Pyramid scheme but we found a loophole.  The only way you can really make money is to recruit and recruit,  but we do have a product, & that is a loophole.  You don't really make money on the product because our distributors that have to keep recruiting,  ARE the customers.   IF they don't buy the products then they don't get the commission for recruiting.  It's brilliant we have Built-in customers that have to buy  products.   We have a constant flow of income coming into the CEOs pocket.  There might be a few of the distributors that started when we 1st started this scheme,  Before the market was saturated,  that made money but just a few.   IF they get too big we just cancel their 1099 contract, &  And that $20000 a month income suddenly is cut off. ( Insert diabolical left here)  About the 99% to 80% of people probably  will only maybe make a couple dollars, if they work non-stop  or most will lose money by trying to keep up  the rank,& having to buy the products. So money is out then in..  Usually resulting in debt.  The beauty is, they'll just keep doing it and doing it. we'll keep telling them you're just not working hard enough and and you just need to stick it out longer.   The time freedom BS, they'll be on their computers or phone 24/7,  Working non-stop but we'll brainwash  them, to think just because they're sitting at home doing it, or on a beach doing it, that they have "time freedom"while their children are at their ankles begging for attention. EVIL GENIUS, AT ITS BEST.   Remember it's not legal because we found that loophole.  An evil scam at its finest. GrossğŸ¤® Side-note- they don't actually get a free car. You just get a $500 car bonus, for hitting a rank. You only get $500 bonus each month so you can make the car lease payment. You have to  Maintain your rank each month to get the money for the payment if not even if it's the next month if you do not maintain that rank you do not get that $500 bonus. Therefore  You are on your own paying for that car lease out of your own pocket it is under your own name therefore on your own credit.

Your two examples had different types of ills, so I want to give the other set of downsides for each:   With taxi apps, the company is actually running a taxi service even though they claim they aren't. The way they're doing it is illegal, because cities require taxis to register and receive a medallion authorizing them to operate. So Uber et al operate illegally and siphon money away from more local taxi companies. There's also less accountability, because Uber will argue in a court case that the driver was an independent contractor and whatever they did was totally on them.   With short-term rental apps, the property owner will see wear and tear on the property. They have to either take care of the repairs and room turns (cleaning, laundry, restocking, etc) or hire a local to do it; either spending more time or more money. The app takes a LOT of the room rate, so you're best bet is using the app as marketing and try to get people to book on your own website instead.   The last statement you made is crucial, and far more important than the rest: if you want your community to economically improve, you need to spend locally, and keep those dollars circulating locally as long as possible. So it's not just spending your money to buy bread from a local bakery, the bakery needs to spend ITS money as locally as possible. Meaning its business loans need to come from a local credit union that has local investors. Its employees need to live in town, or preferably in the neighborhood, so their paychecks get spent here instead of three towns over where they live. And buy as little as possible online! Remember that money is illusory from the civilization-level perspective, what matters is the value created and its permanence; money is economic lubrication but it is not value in itself, so it's the action, the activity of money, which facilitates prosperity. If we could get together and agree on a different currency, like a local town-based currency, opting out of the dollar would be a huge benefit to the extent that everyone actually did it.   And no I'm not talking crypto. That's just a scheme for stock bros to pump and dump away everything you're willing to give (while convincing you that you could be the dumper if you're quick and clever, and massaging your ego to make you feel quick and clever). It's worse than a government-backed currency from a civilization standpoint.

If you have to pay a company to sell their product, instead of the other way around, that's a red flag on itself. Furthermore math doesn't add up, products are often more expensive than other products of similar quality on the market and you make money by sharing into the company's profit from your 'recruits' and the fee they paid to sell the product. Add to that the empty motivational talk that doesn't really say anything specific; the vague language when explaining the product; the social media spam of fake glamour life and the annoying way to 'recruit' by calling people one hasn't seen in years, and you have the checklist of what a pyramid... I mean a MLM scheme looks like. But the way such schemes keep existing and recruiting is a brilliant textbook example of how this particular cult-style type of brainwashing works.

Good call. I had a relative who got involved in a proper pyramid scheme before they got banned and lost a heap of money. I remember my father saying what a stupid idea it was and how with these sorts of business structures, for someone to win, others needed to lose. (She didn't listen and paid for it.) After seeing that in action, I've avoided any pyramid shaped business schemes and tryed to save others from them when I can. It was a learning experience I'm glad I got early as these companies really are vultures. They particularly like to go after the most vunerable, (even turning "friends" into accomplices), make false promises and then bleed them dry and then don't care what happens to them after that.

Many multinational companies have adopted the business model of MLM or Network marketing to promote their products or services but they are not MLM registered. How about that? No good business will tell you desert your family or friends if they don't buy your idea. Like every business entity, there is nothing wrong to invite your friend or any family member to have a look at a business plan or products or services. Everybody has the right to reject or accept a product or service or idea whether from MLM or traditional company, there is nothing wrong with that. If you buy a fake product or item from a company before realising it, does it make the whole industry that that company belongs to a scam. Not every one succeeds in everything. In the traditional business industry not all companies succeed. Some companies fail after a few years and some don't even grow beyond 5 years minimum. Even in employment not all employees have a successful career. Some are even laid off for poor performance. Mind you in every industry there are bad ones and good ones. Some people come together to form a company in a particular industry do swindle or scam unsuspecting people. Thus that make that industry evil? I don't think so. If a particular company has scammed you that does not mean that the industry is scam. Don't just follow the hype, understand the industry and choose wisely.

It doesn't get more simple than this: Do you like Costco? Sam's club or just your regular local supermarket?? what products do you always buy?? which ones you can't live without? Would you go door to door selling them and telling your friends and family how much you love those products and why they should buy them too? Just to make Costco or your regular supermarket money while you get nothing? not even a thank you? No? I wouldn't!! XD XD, but what if Costco and sam's club etc told you, ''hey, we have this special program in which you can recommend those products you love and if somebody comes to our store and buys them you get one dollar, that's it! just one dollar for each product you recomended and was sold at our stores!!'' Would you recommend those products then?? I most definitely would. It's not my job, it't not my business but hey, I'm making a dollar for each product!! It doesn't hurt an extra dollar in my pocket, right? Same as it doesn't hurt one bit to talk about your experience with your products without having to get out there and knock on doors, harrasing strangers to tell them about how happy you are with those products or services. Now, MLM companies take this promoting method to a more systematic and better structured level. The people that you invite to join in have to consume their products in order for you to get a small commission (which once again, are the most basic products that you will purchase anyway somewhere else where you will not get any additional value, certainly earning  way more than a dollar in the process, lol). Imagine you recommend these awesome products to many people and many people buys them, guess what? you get a small commission for each and everyone of those peoples you invite and are consuming excellent, top quality producs of all kinds!! On a monthly basis................is this clear enough????? You need more??? Let's say you always go to one particular movie theater, perhaps you like the customer service there, the popcorn is the best, the seats are the most confortable, it's super clean and neat, you love that place!! and imagine that cinema chain had also, like Costco in our ficticious scenario, a promoting program so you get 50 cents for just recommending the cinema to your friends and family, you and they get some membership card for free and they have to say your name or promoter id so they can say they are buying the movie ticket at their place and are there thanks to you so you can get your 50 cents commision, wouldn't that be amazing??? Now, lets take this a step further just a bit and say you not only are happy going to that cinema every weekend, you love it so much and so on but also want to make money so what do you do? You start making new friends, you expand your social circles, the time will come for you to also tell your new friends about this great movie theater that you enjoy so much and guess what?  It turns out, A LOOOOT of people have heard of that place and were curious, also, a looooot of people likes to go to the movies, can you see where I am going with this?? lots and lots of potential to make extra 50 cents but it gets even more interesting :D :D, what if ''Cineplex'' (The ficticious cinema for this example), in addition to your 50 cent per new guest commision also gives you bonuses, say, 2 dollars for each 2 people in one same day that goes to see a movie at their cinema, voila!! you can make even more money!! The possibilities are unlimited!!.................so, bottom line, any type of business can become MLM, would you say also that COSTO, SAM'S, Mc donalds, Starbucks, Google,.....Youtube (wait! YOUTUBE?? yes!! They have a lot of viewers right? the guy who owns it makes the most money!! And everybody who advertises here are the losers, the ''victims''. He's at the top of the ''pyramid'' XD) are also pyramids?? no, right?, it all takes a little creativity. USANA, AMWAY, JEUNESSE, HERBALIFE, you name it! are NOT a scam. Period. They have had their bad moments, scandals perhaps but are not scams. Not only are they growing, in the middle of pandemic and all while many previously mentioned, REAL companies's franchise stores had to close for good. MLM businesses not only thrives but also keep growing EXPONENTIALLY while many regular businesses are going bankrupt. So, who are you going to believe? the naysayers, even though they are the majority? (but also the majority of mediocre, broke and sad people are those 95% of the world's population to begin with so no surprises there) or the actual and real sales figures and upward trend statitistics? I don't know what you call that but to me that is a great business opportunity, unless you have millions of dollars to open your OWN Costco or mc donalds store, or are brilliant and rich enought to sell the MLM idea to your local supermarket or cinema according to my own examples, go for it! It's a free country and good luck! I'll stick to my MLM company thanky you very much ;)

If you ask me, if you want to get involved in an MLM company do a little research on the company, make sure it is 100% legit, also check out what products they have. Personally, I would not join one MLM company that has very little time in the market, because it is SUPER hard to get started, I would rather join one that has a major presence in the market with sales trends going up and booming. I am sorry to hear that however one thing you must consider is that in order to make money you must be ready to learn their system, you must be open minded, you need to have businness vision. In the beginning you earn little money while the work can be very hard but with time if you keep learning and training you will begin to see results, the money making system in MLM works that way, you don't see much results in the beginning but over time your earnings multiply as you build your team and your network of consumers grows, the beauty of MLM is something called residual income, which is all the commisions you earn through the sales of products throughout your entire network. The myth about MLM is that the only goal is you have to sign up so the guy who invited you gets a commission without any further compensation other than that but what you are doing in reality by inviting people to see your businness plan is selling a mini franchise of the company, like mcdonalds, you see, MLM companies manufacture products of extremely high quality that can't be purchased in stores, millions of dollars in research go into the making of these products but they don't spend much on advertisement as the marketing process is up to us, the associates of these companies, you sell by recommending products to others which in my opinion is something we all do on a daily basis anyway, but in an MLM company you make money whereas recommending a cheeseburger from mcdonalds for example you don't earn a dime, the only way to purchase these products is by becoming a member.....it sounds like a lot of work and hassle but trust me, it pays. With the right leadership, training and hard work you can easily retire in  5 years....It's not a perfect way to  plan your retirement but is waaaay better than working a normal job and retiring old and tired in 40 years......I hope this info helps, you caught me by surprise, lol. Other businesses are not illegal because the people buying most of their products/services are coming from outside the company. In other words, real free market demand. In MLM scams, most of the products/services are being purchased by the distributors, because the products are massively overpriced, and hardly anyone who is not also a distributor is willing to buy the products, with the instruction from their upline that buying the overpriced products is how they got to the level they achieved, so the downline needs to do the same thing to get to their level. There is little to no free market demand, which means the MLM scam is an illegal pyramid. See the logic?

This is a really important distinction in how sustatinable the MLM company is. The company also incestivises leadership as apposed to mass-recruitment with it's bonuses, looking for depth rather than width in the company. They're not all scams, I've seen the clear legitmacy of many first hand. People need to learn the difference between a real MLM and Pyramid Scheme to protect themselves. So they basically "friended" you and strung you along to build trust before they pitched Amway. Wow.  I'm not sure about the "drop shipper" part. A drop shipper is someone who is selling something and doesn't have possession of the item. When you buy the item from them, they order the item from another party having the item sent directly to you from that party. People do that on Ebay and other selling sites. They get the photo of the item off of Wal-Mart or Amazon, then post it for sale on their site like ebay. When a customer buys, it ships from Walmart or Amazon. Seller made a profit from the item you purchased and didn't even have possession of the item. No inventory, no overhead. Ebay now discourages it unless you have a business agreement with a wholesale company and can provide proof.

If anyone approaches me like that I assume it's a scam or some kind of attack. Nobody, but NOBODY, just innocently walks up to someone and says "Bitchin' tie dude, what are your interests, oh really those are exactly the things I love too!".   99% of the time, some rando walks up and tries to talk with me, it's a few quick questions that immediately and inexorably lead to the begging pitch. Or as a pretext to an assault:  "Can I use your phone" (he steals your phone) "Can I have a dollar" (he grabs for your wallet when you take it out and open it in front of him) "Blah blah blah" (he's distracting you, sizing you up and figuring out whether him and his buddy approaching from behind you could roll you)  Or just the sob story that gets increasingly ridiculous until you stop handing him cash.   You need to face the aggressor, look him right in his eye, and give him a firm "NO" without interacting with his story or listening to it, and keep watching him as he walks away until you leave the area. Treat him like a damn dog. If we all did this, people would stop begging, because they'd be working it all day with zero income.   You want to be charitable? You want to feel like you're contributing? Volunteer. Donate to a food bank or shelter. Don't make yourself a victim.

Watch out for ways they have to trap you though. A common one in Vegas is to load prospects onto a bus and drive you way off the strip, into a crap part of that crap-ass town, and if you decide not to sign up after the pitch then you're stuck trying to figure out how to get back on your own. Possibly in 117 degree heat.   Another common one is putting out the pitch and getting hammered 1-on-1 by sales people before you get your free meal. And it's always "sorry folks the food should be coming soon, but here's another speaker" and it's several hours of that. So if you want the freebie, you're being attacked for way longer than you thought ahead of time.   Just remember that whatever the deal they're offering, it'll always be way worse than they make it sound. That's their business model. So if you think you're gonna show up, eat good food, and then walk out without listening to a 3-hour pitch, you might just be gullible enough to join an MLM.

With experience and degrees in both business and clinical psychology - MLM companies use manipulation tactics to sell you the dream. It's the same idea as "the American dream" thats sold to immigrants. The concept of networking and giving in order to receive is great but at the end of the day that is a tool you can start using right this second without the need of giving up your money, time, etc to these "mentors". We're humans living among humans - networking is possible right now! Conversations with people with experience exist and you'll get there. I would still read the books, listen to them speak, but take away what works for you and leave everything that feels funny or requires you to pay for anything.

I'm not positive of the ratio, but thanks to the FTC vs. Amway, the 30/70 rule applies to mlms.  If they can prove that at least 30% of revenue comes from product sales, they aren't technically a pyramid scheme.  Of course, that 30% model does not preclude distributors who often are required to purchase band stockpile the products, whether they sell on to consumers or not.  If legislators had the fruit and veg to stand up to Amway at the time, Herbal Life, essential oil scams, quite a few Trump ventures, wouldn't be the problem they are today.  Distributors make so very, very little in the bottom 90+% in these pyramid schemes, sorry mlms, that it lower annually than a minimum wage job pays weekly or monthly, depending on scheduled hours.  And that minimal money made is BEFORE they have to pay for start-up kits, licensing, promotional materials, and most often fronting the money to purchase the products they hope to sell to consumers.

"Double black diamond" is not exclusive to skiing. It's also used to indicate extremely difficult or dangerous mountain bike trails. Both ski slopes and MTB trails have six levels of difficulty:  White - incredibly easy, even for beginners or first-timers  Green - Easy, beginner friendly  Blue - Intermediate; can still be ridden by some beginners, but offers steeper descents  Black diamond - Difficult/dangerous; should only be ridden by seasoned riders  Double Black Diamond - Extremely difficult/dangerous. Experts only. Trails often include massive features like gap jumps spanning more than 30 ft.  Double Gold Diamond - Extremely dangerous/difficult, even for professional racers and riders. Serious permanent injury or death can occur.   The most I've ever ridden on a mountain bike is a black diamond, and it scared the shit out of me; rock drops, chunky rock gardens, etc.

The products are overpriced, which makes them almost impossible to sell to customers and results in Amway being an illegal pyramid: http://allmlmfacts.org/2016/05/h-r-5230-and-the-fallacy-of-mlm/ , and also according to the FTC and SEC websites and previous court decisions and settlements; and   2. The Tool Scam is hidden profit for the top level distributors only, and the vast majority of distributors operate at a net loss as a result: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d0iFUaiI2hY This is RICO fraud.   For recent examples, google â€œFTCâ€ along with the following companies, one at a time: FHTM, BurnLounge, Zeek, TelexFree, Vemma, Advocare, Neora, Javita, Waiora, Business For Health, and Herbalife.   Make a complaint on the FTC website: https://www.ftccomplaintassistant.gov/?utm_source=takeaction#crnt&panel1-1   Although there is no federal law defining pyramid schemes, the FTC has a long and successful track record of using its Section 5 law prohibiting â€œunfair and deceptiveâ€ business practices to go after MLM scams: https://www.ftc.gov/tips-advice/business-center/guidance/multilevel-marketing which states, in part, â€œNot all multilevel marketing plans are legitimate. If the money you make is based on your sales to the public, it may be a legitimate multilevel marketing plan. If the money you make is based on the number of people you recruit and your sales to them, itâ€™s probably not. It could be a pyramid scheme. Pyramid schemes are illegal, and the vast majority of participants lose money.â€   Read about these and much more at these websites: www.StopTheAmwayToolScam.wordpress.com; www.AllMLMFacts.org; and www.AmwayUKBlog.wordpress.com  Contact me to help shut down Amway and other MLM scams.   Watch this video about Amway and other MLM scams, then forward it to everyone you know, except for current Amway IBOs, and encourage them to do the same. When enough people know, these scams will collapse:   English version: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s6MwGeOm8iI   Spanish version: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cy-O4myeUzg   Visit my YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/Whydoyoubanothers/videos   Listen to my weekly radio/podcast: https://www.buildingfortunesradio.com/scott-johnson-peter-mingils/  Visit my Facebook page: www.Facebook.com/ScottTexJohnson

I made good money from Amway, but not in the way you think. One of my tax clients approached me with an opportunity. He was vague, but the meeting would be held at his office, and he held a senior position at a reputable financial institution, so I went, expecting something real. I realised in the parking lot, by the Amway stickers on every second bumper, that I was getting into a pyramid scheme . He continued magging me to join for months and eventually brought in his tax records. I noticed that his income certificate from Amway fell pathetically short of the expenses involved to earn it, and we claimed a substantial loss for him. Later that year I claimed similar losses for several losers in his 'Amway congregation' and some of them are still our clients, but none have made a net cent from Amway ever. I also got an undeserved reputation for 'knowing a scam from a real deal'. Thank you Amway.

Something else I never hear about this: where I live at least if you sell ANYTHING, you must have a sales tax number and a city privilege license. They are even cracking down on YARD SALES about sales tax now !  If you hold a 4 hour yard sale once in your life you probably won't get nailed, but if you have one every Saturday cops will probably come by and tell you you need to get a sales tax permit, collect the sales tax, and turn it in. Most of the sales tax actually goes to the state, but the city enforces the local collection of it. PLUS you are required nationwide to report any profits you earn, federal law. Depending on whether you incorporate or file with a Schedule C, you are still liable for taxes on profits. That is, of course, if you are fortunate enough to ever show a profit.

Â @jodiv2928Â  The sales tax at yeard sales thing is fairly new, but eBay has been collecting sales tax on used items from the buyer for quite a while.  When they first started , an advantage to buying over eBay new or used was no sales tax unless you  were in the same state as the seller. Then the govt. started making them collect sales tax on new items nationwide, and finally on used items as well. I agree with you 100%, though. Tax was collected on the item when it was sold new, and if it is collected again on a used sale, then it is being double taxed. Same thing on used cars most places, sales tax collected every time they are resold, even if the car has had 6 previous owners. On the MLM people, of course they are selling new items even if they are outdated, but my point was that such MLM people may have to get a sales tax number.

People can deduce that MLM products are not quality goods for a number of reasons, mainly that your earnings come from recruiting a downline and skimming off their commission. That would be insane if profit was my goal. MLM's most sucessful members are the people with the largest downlines. Why is compensation more dependent on recruiting others to while revenue from the unit sales isn't even a factor because the highest earners are the most successful recruiters? Why do these companies with a good product need to rely on the distribution network for profits? Quality brands are only concerned with manufacturing the best possible product. When I was 11, my parents had an MLM phase. One day, school was out, so I insisted that I come with my mom to one of those training seminars for her MLM because I was bored. Somehow, I got to be a part of the audience.  At one point, the facilitator said "Kids today are exposed to too much radiation from tech, you can tell by how the white spots on their nails are bigger compared to adults". I knew that was bullshit, because unlike the rest of the adults in the room, I know that's because younger people grow nails faster. I decided to wait for a moment to troll the guy.   Later on, we had a session where the facilitator would pretend to be someone who has diabetes and the attendees would try to sell an item from their catalog. Then, came my turn. This is my moment. Mic in hand, I listed not just one or two items like the rest, but I went through the whole catalog and mentioned every item that claimed to help with diabetes and added my own layer of bullshit including "protection from radiation". It made the guy very uneasy and I was getting 'the look' from everyone else in the room except my mom, who conveniently was in the bathroom at the time. It was glorious.  I just felt I had to share this story because I never get to bring it up in a conversation lol

My up line emerald was receiving intense pressure by his up line triple diamond   that â€œyour group needs you to go diamondâ€. Basically a threat that if you donâ€™t, youâ€™ll get no more help from me. So my Emerald started telling his peopl they needed to buy product and keep it going for six months so he could qualify for diamond. At the time, these home security systems were brand new and had high PV. Everyone took out loans to buy these up and stored them in their garages. The guy did go diamond, but his directs couldnâ€™t unload these security systems. There was a revolt and complaints to corporate and within a year the whole group was dissolved and everyone lost everything. I was thankful I did not buy any security systems and got out before everything crashed.

Mary Kay has something called a "Husband Unawareness Plan" which is where they will heavily pressure women to hide how much they are spending on the product. They will let them put part of the order on credit card and pay for some of it in cash. They will also even send a special invoice with the product saying "congratulations on winning the contest" so that the husband thinks that his wife hasn't spent any money at all. Of course Mary Kay consultants act like lying to your spouse about spending thousands of dollars is adorable and funny and "just between us girls" but lying about Mary Kay spending is quoted in an alarming number of divorces. There are whole websites dedicated to stories about the "Husband Unawareness Plan" and while Mary Kay consistently tries to claim that it's not a real thing and that if it does happen it's just the act of a couple of rogue consultants it's just too widespread for that to be true. Plus people have legit literature from their uplines about it. They actively encourage this fraud.

Mary Kay has something called a "Husband Unawareness Plan" which is where they will heavily pressure women to hide how much they are spending on the product. They will let them put part of the order on credit card and pay for some of it in cash. They will also even send a special invoice with the product saying "congratulations on winning the contest" so that the husband thinks that his wife hasn't spent any money at all. Of course Mary Kay consultants act like lying to your spouse about spending thousands of dollars is adorable and funny and "just between us girls" but lying about Mary Kay spending is quoted in an alarming number of divorces. There are whole websites dedicated to stories about the "Husband Unawareness Plan" and while Mary Kay consistently tries to claim that it's not a real thing and that if it does happen it's just the act of a couple of rogue consultants it's just too widespread for that to be true. Plus people have legit literature from their uplines about it. They actively encourage this fraud.

When I was 11, my parents had an MLM phase. One day, school was out, so I insisted that I come with my mom to one of those training seminars for her MLM because I was bored. Somehow, I got to be a part of the audience.  At one point, the facilitator said "Kids today are exposed to too much radiation from tech, you can tell by how the white spots on their nails are bigger compared to adults". I knew that was bullshit, because unlike the rest of the adults in the room, I know that's because younger people grow nails faster. I decided to wait for a moment to troll the guy.   Later on, we had a session where the facilitator would pretend to be someone who has diabetes and the attendees would try to sell an item from their catalog. Then, came my turn. This is my moment. Mic in hand, I listed not just one or two items like the rest, but I went through the whole catalog and mentioned every item that claimed to help with diabetes and added my own layer of bullshit including "protection from radiation". It made the guy very uneasy and I was getting 'the look' from everyone else in the room except my mom, who conveniently was in the bathroom at the time. It was glorious.  I just felt I had to share this story because I never get to bring it up in a conversation lol

Before anyone starts bashing on Amway let me educate you. You need $75 to get a license to buy the products at an IBO price (not retail price) and to legally sell their stuff.  If you decide selling is not for you, Amway will REFUND YOUR MONEY ($75 you paid). Pyramid schemes WILL NEVER EVER refund your money. A pyramid scheme makes money from people paying to join and will not give back their only source of income.   Pyramid schemes also never make money from selling their products. They have low quality cheap products that are difficult to sell. The point of the Pyramid scheme was never to sell products its to sell memberships at HIGH PRICES. Amway on the other hand only makes money from REAL SALES of their products.   Recruiting people does not make you money. You selling and the people you have recruited selling products is the way you and Amway make money. Just like any other business, they sell products and they have franchisees with their own locations selling the same products. Amway IS THE SAME except it doesn't have locations, it has PEOPLE.  A pyramid scheme makes you charge people large sums of money which you give a certain percentage back to the company while you keep the rest. It encourages you to have others do the same. Amway is not like that. Amway you pay the $75 for the license directly to Amway. IBOs do not make money recruiting people. Once again, they make money the legitimate way: by selling products.  Pyramid schemes also MAKE YOU buy a certain amount of products to even join. They may make you buy as much as $600 worth of their garbage and then you will be allowed to join.   Amway DOES NOT DO THAT.  All you need is the IBO license and that's it. You can buy as little or as much as you want OR you don't even need to BUY ANYTHING AT ALL. You can set up an official website with them and have your customers buy directly from said website and Amway will package and ship the product FOR YOU AND SEND IT DIRECTLY TO YOUR CUSTOMERS.  Amway makes BILLIONS a year and have been successful for many years. Pyramid schemes always fall apart sooner or later. Amway will never die because it's a legitimate business with legitimate high quality products.

I almost signed up for Mary Kay, but hesitated. A year later, i saw this video. Never even heard of pyramid schemes before then. Not realizing how shady MK is, i went to another Mary Kay party months later. They hold them under the pretense of teaching you a makeup skill, winning makeup samples, and chatting with your gals. But at the end, they hit you with a persuasive speech: "We really want you to join Mary Kay." "You don't really make money by selling product, you make it by recruiting other people. The more people you have under you, the more money you make." The more they talked, the more alarmed i became, realizing how close i had been to signing up for a pyramid scheme/MLM.  For years, i trusted the company because my family trusted them too. The lady that sells Mary Kay to my mother had sold it to my late grandmother for years. She's a friend of the family, she literally came to my grandma's funeral. I saw no reason to distrust the company any more than i would distrust this woman as a person. But now? I want to show her this video.   TL,DR: This video saved me from signing up for an MLM. Thank you, John.

there is money to be made in this stuff. my family has been involved in several mlms for the last 10 years. and there are a few things you can look out for to avoid or at least minimalize the chance of loss. always look for a system that has existed for less than a year and that allows you to make your money back in 4-6 months without doing anything. also avoid systems that are growing too slowly. there is a sweet spot. if it grows faster, it is younger. but if it slows down, it will soon collapse.  but never ever sell physical products. this is a red line, nobody should cross. sell crypto currencies, sell digital goods, fine. but never ever buy anything to sell it. if you do, you will never achieve the freedom you want.  other red flags consist of fixed number of partners, low return of investment, the use of the word family, big promises in general, and flashy shows in general. but those alone are not a sign of something dangerous. also never recruit friends and family, only strangers. because you do not want to poison your home with it. no matter how awesome it seams. if someone asks you what you are doing, tell them, but also warn them. if they still want it, give them. but never convince them. this way it is not your fault when they loose anything.  hope this helps. and no, I am not sabotaging my family with this post. we operate far far away from herbalife. fuck herbalife.

In the 90s the Amway (or the independent motivational organization)'would tell you (10 hours a week and you could make an extra $2000 a month. Once you start buying the tapes they start telling you that you need to leave work at 5, drive up to 4 hours a night, do your meeting, then have the meeting after the meeting (where you sign people up), then go out for coffee with your group, head home at 2am, get home at 5, nap, shower and back to work. You were supposed to spend your weekends driving up to 12 hours away doing meetings. There's monthly open meetings, motivational sessions, then the major events, with lots of rah-rah, a rock  band that transforms itself into a gospel group on Sunday mornings. You tour the motorcoaches, go shopping for stuff you can't afford, and suffer sleep deprivation. I'm sure it works for some.
I did the Amway thing in the 90s. What a trip.

The day has come! I had a very pleasant conversation with my dad, I hopefully understood correctly and I can simply put my thoughts in words. So where do I start.. First of all, all the allegations from members and distributors that the products cure illnesses etc, are just personal experiences, not the company's claims. (except that career book included in the video which the company removed bc of the fancy claims made when the company first launched ).  My dad had an ulcer in the small intestine since birth and it disappeared after using the products. He says that to people as an experience not as a way to pursue them that the x product will cure y illness. Then about the people that bought products in bulk wasting money, well, your supervisor should help you get started with the sales, but some supervisors make new members and leave them figure it out on their own, which doesn't work out. When u first start selling you buy a few products, and when these are sold, u buy more. As for the pyramid scheme title, a man named Bill Ackman spent $50 million on a public relations campaign against Herbalife, which was designed to hurt the company's stock price, that's why he said the company owed him money. Here is the link to the wikipedia page for anyone who's interested. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Ackman#Herbalife_short  I mean, this job is not for everyone. I've told my dad that I can't be anything besides a consumer because I have other goals away from that sales thingy. It's okay. Other than that, I can see where most of the comments' points come from but it's not that big of a deal.. If u want to try it, okay,  just do your research for any MLM to be safe.  Thanks for reading ig have a great day or night, remember not to stress over silly things, be healthy be happy and drink water:))) if you have any further questions?, better search on other more trusted sources

â€œWithin thirteen cycles, you run out of people...â€ I did the math on a basic calculator app on my iPhone, and the result is 6,103,516,000 (rounded up to the nearest thousand because of the mathematical limitations of the app); this is less than the population of the earth. According to Google, the population of the earth in 2016 was 7,426,000,000 (rounded to the nearest million people). I know Iâ€™m being a stickler, and itâ€™s a good point, but technically, it would actually take 14 cycles (5 to the 15th power) to exceed the population of the earth, which ends up amounting to: 30.5176 billion, rounded up to the nearest 100 thousand, again due to the mathematical imprecision of the app I used to calculate this. Try it yourself: 5x5=25, x5=125, x5= 625, etc.... (that is how you want to type it in, using the keys I typed in). If you have a better calculator, you can just type in 5^13, 5^14, and 5^15; and youâ€™ll get the exact same results, but possibly with a higher precision, especially with say: a TI-83 or similar calculator. Yes, Iâ€™m kind of a math nerd, I get it.... Iâ€™m just saying that adding a single digit to the exponent would have absolutely accurate. But the way itâ€™s explained isnâ€™t correct because over 6 billion isnâ€™t exactly â€œexceeding the population of the earthâ€. Itâ€™s close, but itâ€™s not actually exceeding the population of the earth, technically. But the next step very much WOULD, FAAAAR exceeding the population of the earth by many times. Arenâ€™t exponential equations fun, kiddos??? Just kidding, theyâ€™re not that fun. But Iâ€™m right, so..... just buy a calculator and do the actual math before making an erroneous statement. Itâ€™s not that hard. Iâ€™m kind of drunk right now, and I did it. By the way, MLMs are TERRIBLE! My sister conned me into one, and I was charged about $38 a month to buy the basic package for over a year. I didnâ€™t really use much of what I bought. It was a basic package to continue membership. And NO ONE wanted in on it (including me), so I basically wasted over $400 on useless crap in the meantime, while trying to convince friends that it was â€œa tringle-shaped opportunityâ€. Take his advice and stay away from these scamming assholes! Side note: used car salesmen and saleswomen use a similar strategy. I was told on several occasions over 35 years of living: â€œWe have to cover our overhead, and the internet has taken over, so we want your car, but.... itâ€™s not in PERFECT condition [Iâ€™m referring to the sale of several cars WELL under 80,000 miles here], so we will offer you x amount.â€ And that amount was SIGNIFICANTLY lower than the blue book value because â€œKelly Blue Book is unreliable are best, and it doesnâ€™t take into account [our overhead] the â€˜factâ€™ that we will likely sell your car at auction. We donâ€™t get as much at auction because we donâ€™t typically sell your brand of car.â€ Now, some people may say: â€œWhy not go to a BMW dealership to sell a 2005 BMW M3, and then get more money???â€ Well, I tried that, and I was told the same thing. I guess my point here is that salesmen arenâ€™t particular skilled, and they lie and cheat their way into trying to get people to both pay sticker price for a new car and also into taking less than the Kelly Blue Book value for a used car, while also touting ideas like leases... and although some rich people lease brand new cars every couple of years, they donâ€™t realize that one way or another, they are paying for the depreciation of said car... they look at the deal and say: â€œHey, the payments are lower than owning!â€ But the fact is that the depreciation is coming out of their pocket, and for a new German car, that depreciation can be anywhere between $20,000-40,000 OR MORE over the lease period; PLUS they have to return the car to the dealer without having any ownership at all. I have NEVER leased a car, never mind a new one, in my ENTIRE life. I have financed to own several cars, but in the process of trading said cars in, I am offered THOUSANDS less than the car is worth on Kelly Blue Book, no matter what. I even once got a cash offer from Kelly Blue Book for $18,000, only to turn up at their approved dealership, then offered $14,000, which then went down to $12,000 a few days later because â€œthey thought about it and decided they didnâ€™t really want my old Subaru.â€ Anyway, at $12,000-18,000, it was a REALLY nice Subaru with less than 40,000 miles, and they were sticklers about EVERYTHING! I guess my point is that MLMs are like ALL salesmen and saleswomen.... they are ALL con artists, and SHAME ON THEM for making money by LYING for a living... thatâ€™s what Donald J. Chump does, and it hasnâ€™t worked out that great for him either... SURE, he made A LOT of money by lying and defrauding MANY people, but how does he sleep at night??? Iâ€™m MUCH more content in a job that doesnâ€™t involve any dishonesty, while I know I would be MORE than qualified to sell used cars or MLM products, thereby lying and securing a special place in hell by feeding my family as a professional ASSHOLE! One car salesman actually asked me if I wanted to buy any cocaine! (my â€œfriendâ€ at the time was missing a couple of teeth, and I shouldnâ€™t have brought him along for a test drive at an Audi dealership on Cape Cod.... Iâ€™m just sayinâ€™...) True story though! OF COURSE an Audi salesman on CAPE COD thought I wanted cocaine.... thatâ€™d the kind of people that work in this industry.... drug addicts and cheats and liars and ALL OF THE ABOVE!!!! Side note: I donâ€™t do cocaine, and I NEVER have.... but this idiot I felt bad for and used to hang out with actually did at times, and the used car salesman saw this from a MILE away! I should have too, and I probably wouldnâ€™t have talked to the prick to begin with.... I digress.... but ANY good salesman has ONE trait in common: â€œBusiness Ethics??? WTF IS THAT?!????â€ I had another friend who worked at Sears, and he was their TOP TV salesman... however, he was honest with customers and told them: â€œyou donâ€™t really NEED to buy the extended warranty, itâ€™s a scam!â€ He had repeat customers that specifically requested him because he was honest and well-meaning....
